hero.headline: Wound Healing
hero.description: Wound closure devices face unique challenges proving healing acceleration while preventing infection and minimizing scar formation. We test closure effectiveness, tissue integration, and healing quality using standardized wound models that address both 510(k) and PMA regulatory pathways.

primary_content.title: Our Preclinical Expertise
primary_content.description:
Wound healing devices must prove they accelerate closure progression while maintaining tissue integrity and preventing complications that compromise therapeutic outcomes. Closure devices need to demonstrate tensile strength development that protects wounds from dehiscence while negative pressure systems require validation of pressure distribution uniformity across wound beds. Advanced dressings must show moisture balance maintenance that supports epithelialization without creating maceration conditions. Each technology addresses different healing phase requirements, from initial hemostasis through granulation tissue formation to final epithelialization and remodeling stages.

We evaluate healing progression using planimetric imaging that tracks wound area reduction over time while histopathological analysis characterizes tissue quality at closure sites. Mechanical testing quantifies tensile strength development across healing phases while specialized wound models replicate acute surgical incisions, chronic ulcer conditions, and infected wound scenarios requiring validated assessment. Our protocols measure granulation tissue formation quality, collagen deposition patterns, and epithelialization rates using standardized histological scoring systems. We track inflammatory cell infiltration dynamics, angiogenesis progression, and extracellular matrix remodeling that determine functional healing outcomes.

ISO 10993 biocompatibility standards guide dermal contact assessment while wound-specific protocols address both acute and chronic healing validation requirements. Testing supports 510(k) pathways for devices demonstrating substantial equivalence to cleared wound management technologies and PMA submissions for breakthrough healing platforms requiring comprehensive effectiveness demonstration. Whether validating surgical closure devices, negative pressure therapy systems, or tissue scaffolds promoting chronic wound resolution, our protocols generate data addressing FDA wound healing device guidance expectations.

capabilities.title: Wound Closure Rate Quantification
capabilities.description: Planimetric imaging analysis tracks wound area reduction throughout healing phases while measuring closure progression kinetics that demonstrate healing acceleration compared to standard care control groups using statistically validated assessment methodologies.

capabilities.title: Granulation Tissue Quality Assessment
capabilities.description: Histopathological evaluation characterizes granulation tissue formation using standardized scoring systems that quantify cellular infiltration patterns, angiogenesis density, and extracellular matrix composition throughout wound bed maturation phases.

capabilities.title: Tensile Strength Development
capabilities.description: Mechanical testing measures wound tensile strength progression across healing time points while evaluating suture retention forces and tissue resistance to dehiscence under physiological stress conditions replicating patient activity levels.

capabilities.title: Epithelialization Progression
capabilities.description: Quantitative immunohistochemistry tracks keratinocyte migration and epithelial layer formation across wound surfaces while measuring re-epithelialization rates that determine complete wound closure achievement and barrier function restoration.

capabilities.title: Scar Formation Characterization
capabilities.description: Collagen organization analysis using polarized light microscopy quantifies scar tissue quality while measuring scar width, elevation characteristics, and fibrosis extent that determine cosmetic outcomes and functional tissue restoration.

capabilities.title: Biocompatibility and Tissue Response
capabilities.description: ISO 10993-10 dermal irritation and sensitization protocols evaluate allergic response potential while chronic implantation studies assess inflammatory cell infiltration, foreign body response development, and long-term tissue integration at device-tissue interfaces.

cards.title: Healing Progression Expertise
cards.description: Validated wound models replicate acute surgical incisions, chronic venous ulcers, diabetic wound conditions, and pressure ulcer scenarios enabling device performance assessment across clinically relevant healing challenges. Our team understands wound bed preparation requirements, healing phase dynamics, and tissue remodeling processes that device manufacturers must address for regulatory submissions. This expertise translates to protocol designs capturing healing acceleration demonstration, infection prevention validation, and scar minimization evidence that FDA wound healing device pathways require.

cards.title: Dermal Device Regulatory Success
cards.description: Successful FDA submissions across wound closure systems, negative pressure therapy platforms, and tissue scaffold technologies demonstrate our ability to generate data addressing reviewer expectations for wound healing devices. We understand both 510(k) substantial equivalence pathways and PMA breakthrough device requirements including chronic wound healing demonstration, biocompatibility validation per ISO 10993 dermal contact standards, and the specific healing progression endpoints FDA expects for wound management technology approvals.
